title: Before 3 November 2020, will federal legislation to provide at least $5 billion in new direct financial assistance to the United States Postal Service (USPS) become law?
preds: Unlikely unless tied to stimulus deal.
(no change) We'll see how the opposite of "suppress the vote" turns out in a few days (or weeks).

Updates:
— "Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin delivered a downbeat assessment Friday about his economic stimulus talks with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), saying the speaker had 'dug in' and 'significant differences' remain ... the soonest Congress is likely to act would be in the 'lame duck' session following the election. Lawmakers will be facing a Dec. 11 government shutdown deadline and will have to pass a new spending bill. It’s possible some coronavirus relief measures could be attached." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/10/23/trump-congress-coronavirus-bailout/
— "Optimism faded on Friday for a pre-election breakthrough on a stimulus measure to stabilize a shaky pandemic-era recovery, as negotiations between leading congressional Democrats and the White House limped past yet another self-imposed milestone with no deal and no resolution in sight ... With only six workdays remaining before Election Day, time has essentially run out for a stimulus deal to be enacted before the final day of balloting, with Ms. Pelosi previously telling reporters that text would need to be completed by the end of this week in order to become law by Nov. 3." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/23/us/politics/congress-trump-stimulus-deal.html Revising downward.
Down 5%. The US used to be able to have nice things. :-(

It seems like the COVID relief package that Pelosi and Mnuchin are negotiating has $ for the USPS — "the package ... [includes] billions for the U.S. Postal Service." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/10/22/trump-congress-coronavirus-bailout/ And the two sides seem close to a deal! But Election Day is right around the corner and it does not seem likely that the Senate will vote for any package before then — and that's assuming that the 13 GOP votes are all there. https://twitter.com/JakeSherman/status/1319404100359016448

At this point the chance of a bailout happening is extremely low, although both sides are still talking about it. It will take too much time for both sides to reach a decision, and the democrats will likely just punt it to after the election to make a real decision.
-9. They're shooting for the end of the week but apparently they're still far off. https://www.forexlive.com/news/!/meadows-says-talks-have-finished-for-the-day-still-a-way-to-go-20201020

Going back up on this. Seems like strong desire on both sides to reach a deal. McConnell may be open to allowing a vote on a compromise deal and if he did that I think it would pass. But time is very short and the two sides have been "narrowing in" for a while now. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/19/coronavirus-stimulus-pelosi-and-mnuchin-discuss-relief-bill.html "If Speaker Pelosi ever lets the House reach a bipartisan agreement with the Administration, the Senate would of course consider it."
https://www.republicanleader.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/mcconnell-on-covid-19-relief-and-senate-schedule

From POLITICO's Playbook: "About 20 or so hours ago, Washington’s most eager man -- Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin -- said what we’ve been trying to say for weeks about Covid relief: 'At this point, getting something done before the election and executing on that will be difficult.' ... it seems completely plausible that Covid relief not only will be delayed for now, but could be delayed for several months, and could even slip into late in the first quarter of 2021." https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook/2020/10/15/is-covid-relief-ever-going-to-happen-490609

+2. I'm jumping back and forth on this now. Looks like they're still in talks. Senate may refuse to pick it up even if they do get something done. Going from no chance to about 1 in 50 chance. https://twitter.com/kaylatausche/status/1316719829819305993
Negligible chance now it seems, there was a slim chance last week but no progress being made and time is running out.

There is a largish faction among the policy makers of the US gummint fervently committed to free and fair elections as long as they get to pick the voters.   Hard to do with mail votes because you can't tell by looking at an envelope the skin colour, sex, or economic class of the sender.    These being key variables for the selection of voters in that form of free and fair election, democracy can best be preserved by not allowing any of That Sort Of Thing unless the envelopes come from a specific resort in Florida.  This is probably in the Constitution, written with a Sharpie.

+3.  Hard to keep track of what's going on with all the flailing from the white house. Sure seems like the timeline is too tight and McConnell is too uninterested to get it done before November third. https://twitter.com/JakeSherman/status/1314542811547676672
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/09/coronavirus-stimulus-mitch-mcconnell-says-relief-deal-unlikely-soon.html

-4. Was at 5 hoping someone would have some sense and get the president on board, but there's little chance of anything happening it seems. "McConnell said that the Senate will 'reengage after the election.'" https://www.marketwatch.com/story/mnuchin-and-pelosi-resume-discussions-after-trump-changes-of-course-on-fiscal-stimulus-11602082017
Down 40%. On a positive note, after the election there will be an omnibus bill that provides support/stimulus, infrastructure, gold-plated healthcare, and the platinum plan.
No stimulus coming before the election.
Back to zero in light of this afternoon’s presidential temper tantrum.
(no change) Who (which party) needs it more before the election? (rhetorical question; one with many answers, some of them true)
From this point onwards, -1% every two days.

+10, going from about 1 in 4 to a little over 1 in 3 probability on recent news. Sounds like both sides (House and White House) want a deal and are compromising. Remains to be seen if the Senate will go for it. https://twitter.com/JStein_WaPo/status/1312098986371674112
Recent presidential debate renewed skepticism by the crowd even about the chances of loans. Lowering to 25%, with negative outlook.

Up 10%. The GOP Senate can't take the negative consequences of doing nothing (what they do best though). 1 October is when some of the dominoes (airlines, etc.) begin to fall. They just have to have Mnuchin and Pelosi cut a deal.
Little chance it will get through senate.
Late to the party, but Trump is tearing the place down. No money for UPS.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/09/30/congress-white-house-economic-stimulus/
Talks happened, but nothing was concluded -1% every two days.

+10. Pelosi and Mnuchin meeting today. Both sides have lots of reason to want to get this done, both politically and just for the health of the country in general. I think 1 in 4 is a good chance for right now, this needs to happen but there are still lots of hurdles to overcome. https://twitter.com/JakeSherman/status/1311329683867303937
As long as Trump said what he said in the first debate no!
+5 on news of bill offered by Democrats and renewed talks. Timing will probably be tight and not much room for things to break down again. Will increase if it looks like progress is being made.
Going down 1% every 2 days. Going up 4% on account of Pelosi's push

Update: "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi abruptly shifted course Thursday and moved to assemble a new coronavirus relief bill to form the basis for renewed talks with the White House, amid mounting pressure from moderates in her caucus and increasingly alarming economic news ... she said the new bill would be around $2.4 trillion ... Republicans dismissed Pelosi’s move as insincere, noting that she was increasing her asking price from $2.2 trillion to $2.4 trillion before talks had even begun ... Partisan disputes that sank earlier negotiations — including Democrats’ demands for generous state and local aid and Republicans’ insistence on liability protections for businesses — also showed little sign of having been resolved." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/09/24/congress-coronavirus-economic-relief/
Up 10% on Mnuchin/Pelosi talks. $5B lost in noise and the GOP Senate does not have a winning hand. YMMV
I can't imagine Trump signing it
Going down 1% every two days. Going a further 5% down on account of RGB's death and further distractions
There is too much drama around the election and the supreme court issues. They will hold this issue hostage.

Dems are approaching the election passively and would need to swing the Senate which has no incentive to change its position on this. The Dems would need to offer the GOP something and I don't see what that could be at this stage. Current backlog in passing legislation also makes this very, very unlikely to happen especially given the diplomatic hurdles to be overcome.

Looking increasingly unlikely that a coronavirus bill happens with all the other things going on and the upcoming supreme court nomination, and I don't see this happening separately from a coronavirus bill.
Down 15%. Only some much time and oxygen.

McConnell has different priorities (SCOTUS) and Democrats are always on the defense with little to no offense. Plus they may not want to hand Trump this victory at this point so close to the election.

Adjustment for the passage of time: drop ~1% every two days Other adjustments: https://en.as.com/en/2020/09/20/latest_news/1600633500_025776.html As is an Spanish sports newspaper, but it has some recent clear-headed coverage.
Maybe a 40% chance that a bill passes, 50% that it gives USPS 5 billion, and 70% that it does so before Nov.
This would hurt GOP chances in November so highly unlikely to pass Senate
There is no political will to do this
Down 60% to be closer to the consensus.
-10. The death of RBG I think will decrease any feelings of compromise.

https://www.govexec.com/management/2020/09/senate-fails-pass-coronavirus-bill-would-have-provided-10b-postal-service/168384/
https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/15/nancy-pelosi-house-coronavirus-deal-415112 https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-urges-republicans-back-bigger-coronavirus-bill/story?id=73047834
I did not think a deal would happen before the election but it looks more possible now. Going to raise.
-10 because it sounds like there's little interest in compromise or starting from the Problem Solvers framework.
Under Trump and given the gridlock in Congress, the chances of more aid being allocated to the Post Office is almost zero.

Dropping score because its been out of the news cycle quite a bit recently, and the pressure has definitely lifted while the USPS is no longer openly dismantling machines, etc. It seems like they're also not making a big deal about running out of money before the end of the year though.
It seems like its still being debated as part of a larger covid-19 stimulus though, and I do think the Trump administration is highly incentivized to get that passed so that people can get some individual bail-out before the election.
https://www.govexec.com/management/2020/09/senate-fails-pass-coronavirus-bill-would-have-provided-10b-postal-service/168384/
Perhaps nothing will happen before the election.

-11 on passage of time and apparent indifference in the Senate (talk of ending session for campaign season in a few weeks). But a new proposal for a 1.5 trillion package came out and has $15 trillion in USPS aid. Will update in a few days once we see if there's interest in compromise. https://problemsolverscaucus-gottheimer.house.gov/media/press-releases/problem-solvers-caucus-unveil-march-common-ground-covid-stimulus-framework
Dropping a little bit with the passage of time, and as I get a better understanding. Maybe drop ~1% every two days from here on.

Good background
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/up-front/2020/08/26/how-is-the-u-s-postal-service-governed-and-funded/
~6 weeks to resolve this. Given lack of info and contentious nature, always side on ability of politicians to kick can down the road. Will either be other person’s problem or you can blame other person for the distraction. So I’m dropping substantially.
-3%. Generally less news flow around passing a bill where this could be attached.

(no change) I don't see after a quick read that CARES related stuff is excluded.  My inclination is that the operative issue is there >$5B? If there is a line of credit, whether it is immediately accessed or not, I'd vote a yes.

+6 to 51, since I still think this funding is more likely than not. I also found that the GOP "skinny" bill had $10 billion of loan forgiveness for the USPS, which I'm guessing wouldn't count based on the question wording. http://www.wicz.com/story/42604587/heres-whats-in-the-gops-skinny-stimulus-bill-and-whats-missing
-15 on latest events of "skinny" bill and lack of progress on this.
Up 70% on the (CARES) loan mentioned below. If it looks like a duck . . . ??

Not sure if anyone raised this previously... I get crowd forecast low. I may be on wrong side here...
https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm1071
I'm coming to the conclusion that I was on the wrong side of this one. Still, I'm choosing to stay higher than the crowd for now.
The gloves are off...but they already were..so bare knuckles then.
Down another 15% in a race to the bottom (of the forecast).
Ok - I’m starting to question my reasoning. Time for deeper dive...

"Senate Democrats blocked a scaled-down, $500 billion Republican coronavirus relief measure Thursday ... Thursday’s vote may be the final chance for congressional leaders and the White House to forge a compromise on an economic stimulus bill. High-level negotiations have gone nowhere. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, one of the White House’s chief negotiators, cast doubt this week on whether Congress would pass another coronavirus relief package. He instead seemed focused on making sure that federal agencies remain open past the Sept. 30 funding deadline rather than cutting a deal with Democrats." https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/10/senate-coronavirus-relief-package-411635
Hedging toward crowd and due to passage of time.
Becoming increasingly pessimistic any deal is going to happen.
Think there will be some funding but amount may be lower

Based on a report from ABC news that I read, president Trump had stated that he would block efforts at bailing out the USPS, and Mitch McConnell had stated that there was no rush to bail them out either. I think that it will be prevented for political reasons.

Good overview of where we're at: https://www.wsj.com/articles/lawmakers-tackle-spending-deadline-look-to-revive-coronavirus-aid-talks-11599480001 The probability of a deal occurring before the election is falling.
Hard for anything to become law prior to the election.

I may have under-estimated this one. There is already an agreement in place that they can call on loan. I don’t know this satisfies the question with “loans would count”? Does sound like something has to happen close of question - but used to governments finding a third or forth way ;)
“Recognizing the USPS’s dire financial situation, the federal government in March sought to intervene. The Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act authorized the Postal Service to take a $10 billion loan from the U.S. Treasury. According to a recent agreement, the Postal Service can borrow the money if it determines that it will not be able to fund operating expenses due to the coronavirus pandemic. In April, the USPS told Congress it would run out of money by September and requested $75 billion in emergency funding. ”
https://www.forbes.com/sites/advisor/2020/08/07/why-the-usps-is-a-controversial-player-in-the-second-stimulus-bill/

I’m staying low but acknowledge I don’t have greatest understanding of US pork barrel politics and how quickly it might move close to an election. Even if funding in place, I don’t know it would make a difference for mail-in voting given short window. Otherwise, could wait post election. Flip side is Trump could sell it as part of his master deal-making ability (down from $25B to $5B and a postal delivery job for Eric Trump to keep him out if trouble ).
Going down on news that September budget will be decided separately
(no change) Clean CR rumors clear the deck for something later. —not that any agreement is obvious in the Magic 8 Ball (tm).
Another stimulus will likely to be completed before Nov 3, it is likely to be much larger than $5 billion, USPS is very important for dems. $5 billion is a small sum to tack on.

Despite Trump making noises that sound like he'll never support more money for the post office, I assume that is negotiation tactics and will be truly non-negotiable for Democrats in the inevitable upcoming budget sausage-making festival. And some Republicans will support a proposal so long as it sends money and jobs to their districts. I'm not ready to call it 100% like some smart people. I think there is a chance of it getting blown up in negotiations.
house will approve... Mitch will stalemate until elections are over.
Down 10%. Only so much bandwidth and keeping the USG "open" will become more urgent in the next few weeks. https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/01/politics/senate-gop-stimulus-negotiations-plan/index.html

The $25B bill has passed the House of Representatives on Saturday Aug 22, but now faces the Senate and White House
Very public anti-USPS sentiment from GOP
USPS has already stopped canceling plans to remove mailboxes and sorting machine equipment and scale back overtime because of the public backlash and legal threats from states
USPS has 92% confidence rating/support from general public, one of the most positively-seen american institutions
Donald Trump claiming he would only approve money if its part of a larger covid-19 relief package and would veto if it came to his desk today Very likely the debate will increase, and the backlash will get stronger. The USPS needs to keep being funded, and $5B is a lot less than the $25B originally proposed. I think it would also benefit Trump quite a bit to see the larger covid-19 relief package go out before the election, and so they'll likely land on a compromise
It could be part of a larger funding proposal. Will wait and watch

Does not seem likely. Trump is going to veto any legislation that tries to directly aid the post office, for his own benefit. The $$ might sneak through as part of a broader package, though - hence up to 45%. I still have a feeling this may not go as expected.

House has passed funding legislation but there's little chance of this getting through the Senate. Trump has also said he would veto s funding Bill. The only slim chance of USPS getting funding is if the electorate get really vocal about it
Going to 90% on the strength of @cafebedouin's conviction.

The USPS is in financial distress and has stated it has sufficient liquidity to survive through at least August 2021. It's been requesting more funds and it's very popular, so I expect it to receive some of the requested funding, potentially as part of a compromise on new stimulus when the Senate returns from recess in September. Current bills by the house include bans on cost cutting measures and may be larger than Senate Republicans want so are unlikely to go anywhere, and Trump has indicated he would veto those. Putting this at lower confidence because Trump may resist funding for them and it could get delayed since the need isn't as immediately pressing until next year. Since a loan counts that may make this a little more likely than otherwise. https://gen.medium.com/stop-panicking-about-the-post-office-8bcd689b9601
https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/22/politics/postal-service-house-vote-funding/index.html

Tough call for a non-US citizen. The amount mentioned by GJ does not seem as high as necessary to get a bailout on USPS, but even if the 25Bn will be vetoed, a "skinny" coronavirus stimulus package called the Delivering Immediate Relief to America's Families, Schools and Small Businesses Act is being planned by the Senate Republicans, including a 10 Bn allocation for USPS (https://www.cnet.com/how-to/what-the-new-usps-bill-means-for-the-next-stimulus-package/). This should save the day for the Postal Service and the mailed ballots. A refusal by Trump might backfire on him (only a fraction of the GOP voters fell for the Covid negationism, and might want to use the ballot via mail option). So I believe we're over 50%.

...McConnell also suggested $10 billion for the Postal Service, which is less than the $25 billion mail rescue Pelosi and Democrats approved Saturday during widespread postal disruptions. https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/08/27/us/politics/ap-us-virus-outbreak-congress.html
This has become a partisan issue, so it'll be tough to find a majority of Senate Republicans wanting to bring it to a vote
President Trump would veto this and there would not be a supermajority in the Senate to overturn this. The situation would have to change significantly for this not to happen.
Thanks @cdob63 for setting the context. But consider that USPS funding could be part of other funding bills, which will make difficult for Trump to veto it.
Thinking they still have an overall budget to pass so could be included. Initial.

Let us pause for a moment and remember that a bill doesn't become law unless the president either signs it or sits on it.  A veto, unless overridden by extraordinary majorities in the Congress, makes this a No.   If Distinguished Senate Majority Leader Yertle the Turtle accidentally lets this come to a vote and get passed, The Current Incumbent will almost surely veto it and there will not be enough votes in either chamber to override.   There is an off-chance that somebody will distract with some shiny objects long enough (ten calendar days, except Sundays) for it to become law without his signature.  More likely, his sock puppet Postmaster General will alert him to the spectre of high turnout and he'll get around to working his tiny little fingers around a pen and vetoing.   So 6% is probably too high for this particular question. It is very likely that a substantially smaller amount will be approved by the Congress and signed by The Great And Powerful Oz., but this amount is a no-go.
House passed a bill and some Republicans in the Senate seem open to it. Setting a tentative base rate.

It seems that partisan issues, which the post office has clearly become, are extremely unlikely to be solved in the current Congress (and under the current administration). The only possibility I see is if the economic crisis becomes so acute that Republicans concede funding for the post office as part of a general relief bill. That will only happen if there is fairly strong Republican concensus that such a move would be electorally advantageous.
The acute economic crisis is very likely (~90%), but concensus between the various Republican factions seems unlikely (~20%), and even then successful negotiations with Democrats are uncertain (~75%).

The postal service board of governors (Republicans and Democrats) proposed $25B public subsidy. House Democrats running with it. Trump not keen. The question might be how much of a difference this could make in short-term for election. Whatever you think of DeJoy he does know logistics. Besides any reduction has been stopped. Add it all up and I suspect little change under current administration.
I'm going to go contrarian on this for now. The question is "become law" and Trump has already threatened to veto legislation that comes to him that would help the postal service.

"The House passed a bill Saturday to put $25 billion in emergency funding into the U.S. Postal Service and reverse recent operational changes ... The legislation, which comes amid failure to put money into the postal service as part of a broader coronavirus relief plan, is unlikely to get through the Senate." https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/22/usps-news-house-passes-postal-service-funding-bill.html

Initial forecast. Glad GJO included loans in the explanation. Rounding error to almost any relief package and much less than proposed $25B. (-and to further beat a dead horse, might easily be packaged as helping move the mail as opposed to supporting vote by mail—a "win" for all)
